conclusion: Two positive point charges Q are located at points A and B.
Point O is the midpoint between A and B.
Point M is above O on the perpendicular bisector and N is below O.
The distance from O to M and from O to N is sqrt(2)L.
The potential at infinity is zero.
From the potential graph in figure (b), the potential at M is sqrt(2)kQ/L.
The electric force on S1 at M is due to both charges at A and B.
The force due to a charge at A (or B) is FA = kQ^2/(2L)^2, considering the distance is 2L from M to A or B.
The forces from A and B are equal and in the same vertical direction.
The total force FM is the vector sum of the forces from both charges.
Each force component from A or B is FA = kQ^2/(2L)^2.
Since both charges contribute equally, FM = 2FA.
From the analysis and diagram, itâ€™s clear that the force magnitude at M should be consistent with the potential and acceleration data.
The force FM is found to be sqrt(2)kQ/L^2 from the potential analysis.
The magnitude of the electric force experienced by the small ball S1 at point M is FM = sqrt(2)kQ/L^2.
